title: FTSE Bursts Through 7400 Thanks To Sterling Schadenfreude
text:
Despite an industrial contraction in China, the impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump, concerns over global growth and Britain’s political dumpster fire, the European markets were keen to end the final full week of September with a smile.

Unlike the Asian indices, which continued their rough week, Europe woke up with a spring in its step. The neared 12350 thanks to a 50 point increase, while the rose half a percent, allowing it to return to the 5640 levels abandoned on Tuesday.

Just as was the case on Thursday, the left its peers in the dust. Climbing 0.9%, the UK index burst through 7400 for the first time in almost 2-months, cementing a rise that has seen it steadily recover from the lows struck at the end of August.

The primary reason for the index’s buoyancy was its schadenfreude at the state of the pound. Sterling lost another 0.4% against the , forcing it to a near-3-week nadir of $1.228, while against the the currency was down 0.2% and at a fortnight’s low of €1.12535. Bank of England policymaker that the Brexit uncertainty may force a hasn’t help the pound out, adding to the headache caused by the increasingly loud drum of those seeking a general election.
